Johils Hopkins wreaked severe
vengeance on Haverford for her
defeat at the hands of the Scarlet
and Black in football this fall.
The 37-12 score shows well the
vast improvement which Coach
Murphy's charges have undergone
since the game of a week ago.
Haverford had a fast, scrappy
team; but against the superior
weight and strength, coupled with
the extraordinary brand of teamwork- exhibited on the part of the
Black and Blue quint, the Pennsylvanians stood but little show.
Almost entirely was the ball in
the hands of the local basketeers,
who, instead of shooting wildly, as
they have in previous games,
worked the ball to the shadow of.
the basket before attempting a
shot. Only four long shots were
attempted throughout the fracas,
three by Cline°, all of which
failed, and one by Weiner,,which
found its mark.
"Joe" Weiner, who was the
principal offender on this point
last Friday, pushed himself heroically to the rear, watching closely to find a man free, to whom
he shot the leather, only once
obeying the impulse to try a howitzer shot, which luckily hit the
target. Then -he looked at Coach
Murphy and decided that it was
better for him to resume his former playing. He shared the honors of the evening With "Dutch"
Scheurich, who, aided by the former's clever dodging and passwork, chalked up several baskets to his credit.
Stalwart "Bill" Wood, too, deserves a lot of praise for the remarkable way in which he defended the Black and Blue goal.
To the casual observer, "Bill" was
not shining to any extent, but
when it is realized that only four
field goals were scored through
him during the evening, one must
concede that to the.stocky guard
must go a good deal of credit.
It must be admitted that although "Bas",Kennady is a little
weak on covering his man in the
whole game, not once was Walton
able to out-jump him.
The teamwork of Weiner and
SCheurich gave the fans many a
thrill. Time and again "Joe"
dribbled the pigskin through the
entire Haverford quint, to shoot
it to "Dutch," who dashed under
the basket and by a well-placed
shot let the ball roll through the
netting.

At a recent meeting of the Dramatic Club the future activities
of the club were decided upon.,
"The Admirable Crichton" will
again be presented sometime between Easter and May 1, the final
date to be chosen later, thus giving all who were unable to attend
the Christmas production an opportunity to see the play. In
bringing "The Admirable Crichton" before the public once more
the club is yeilding to the entreaties of its many friends, both those
Who did and those who did not see
the first performance, and is relying upon the co-operation of
those interested in the activities
of the University in general, or
the work of the club in particular, to assure it a second successful presentation.
In order that the club might
not remain stationary in its enrollment and the active interest
of the student body thereby languish, it was decided to present,
sometime before Easter, a series
of one-act plays, two or three in
number, one of which, if possible,
to be written by a member of the
University. Insofar as is practical the preference in the selection
of the casts of these plays will be
given to new men—"undeveloped
talent," as it were. Thus the club,
looking into the future, particularly urges all under-classmen who
in any way think themselves qualified for this sort of work to be on
hand when the call is made for
try-outs.
Participation in these plays will
count as usual toward membership in the club, although it is
intended to present them to a limited audience in some hall in
town — the one above the Lyric
having been suggested.
The preparation of this series of
small plays marks the entrance of
the club into a new phase of its
activity, the acting of plays written by Hopkins men, for it is
hoped that the first of this series

origin as well as in presentation.

A mass-meeting was held last
Thursday in the civil engineering
lecture hall for the purpose of
determining the sentiment of the
undergraduate body on boxing as
a Hopkins sport. Mr. Murphy announced the favorable feeling of
the Athletic Board on this matter
and said it was now up to the students to decide whether they
wished to adopt boxing as a regular sport or not. The National
Inter-collegiate Association has
given its sanction to boxing and
it has been instituted in eleven
large colleges.
If Hopkins should develop a
boxing team, our example would
probably be followed in nearby
colleges and we could have boxing tournaments with them as
well as the usual contests. Maryland State already has a team
and is very anxious to stage a
tournament with us.
According to Mr. Murphy, we
have now three or four experienced boxers and with the bringing to light of a few "dark
horses" we could be very credibly
represented in this branch of athletics.
Mr. Murphy explained that it
would be necessary for the students to show considerable interest in boxing in order to win the
recognition of the A. A. Board,
hire coaches, arrange schedules,
etc. The men present were interested to such an extent that an
organization meeting will be
called sometime this week.

All those Ivho ventured forth in
the stormy weather on the eneving of January 16 to hear the lecture given under the auspices of
the Literary Club were fully repaid. The audience was small,
but what it lacked in numbers it
made up in enthusiasm and appreciation. This was the first of
a series of lectures to be given by
the club and it was most fitting
that Edward Lucas White, a Hopkins alumnus and a novelist of no
small repute (his "El Supremo"
took the first prize for its year)
should sponsor the initial literary
venture of the University. Mr.
White's interesting personality
and exuberant humor added much
to the zest and sparkle of the lecture, the subject of which was
"Free Verse and Kindred Forms
of Expression."
Mr. White, after relating the
free verse movement to the whole
body of English and European literature, and showing that from
Homer down the art of writing
poetry is essentially the same,
said in part:
"The free verse writers have the
ambition to compose verse, but
have not the ability to get around
the limitations of a set form. Set
forms to the natural poet are not
bonds, but are more like greased
grooves on which to slide their
verses. Free verse writers are to
be excused because of two great
fallacies:.First, the pioneering fallacy of not learning all the learning of the age, because it dims
originality; secondly, the democratic fallacy of letting democracy
in spirit and speech run rampant.
Free verse does not think apprenticeship necessary. The task of
the poet should be to have something to say—to say it forcibly
and beautifully. Most of the
writers of free verse have nothing
or very little to say. Some of it
is very forceful and has a real
pang of revelation of character
and situation in it. The free verse
movement is not a normal, healthy
growth, but is like a wen on the
side of a man's head or a pimple
on the nose. It is going to pass
away like Pope's couplets. I am
astonished that there is a free
verse movement from the point of
view of a student of English prosody, because of the variety of verse
forms that have not been practiced. The whole movement is
only a temporary and transient
ill usion.

Carnegie Medal Awarded to Murray.

The late Edwin E. Murray, a
third-year student in chemistry
last year at the Johns Hopkins
University, has been named to receive the Carnegie medal for an
act of conspicuous bravery. He
lost his life while attempting to
rescue J. Edward Gibson, of Baltimore, from drowning. Murray
was one of the five men selected
from Hopkins to attend the officers' training school at Fortress
Monroe last fall.

Edwin Litchfield Turnbull,
Johns Hopkins '93, well-known
real estate man and president of
the Johns Hopkins Musical Association, has decided to retire from
the business with which he has
been associated for the past 25
years, in order to devote himself
exclusively to the promotion of
music in Baltimore.
"There has never been a time,"
said Mr. Turnbull, when recently
interviewed about his move,"when
the world was more in need of
music and I believe good music
will be an antidote for the forces
of unrest which are disrupting
war-tortured Europe and creating
havoc in our own country. Music
has proved a tremendous militant
force during the war and indispensable to our soldiers and sailors. There is a far greater need
for music now in the reconstruction period after the war, and
leading business and professional
men must realize that no city,
however progressive from a commercial standpoint, can become a
great metropolis unless a liberal
patronage is given to the arts.
Many smaller cities—Detroit, Cincinnati, St. Louis, San Francisco
—support splendid orchestras and
send them out on annual tours, advertising their cities far and wide.
"This is what I want to see accomplished for our symphony orchestra and then there is another
hobby in which I am deeply interested—it is a desire to see an
endowed department of music at
the Johns Hopkins University,
with courses of study, lectures,
recitals and concerts—and accommodations for a large chorus and
orchestra."
After graduating from Hopkins
in 1893, Mr. Turnbull went to
Europe to study music. While
there he composed his first orchestral composition, and dedicated it to the amateur orchestra he
had founded in America. In 1894
he returned to this country and
entered the real estate business,
remaining in it ever since. During all that time he kept his interest in music and participated
in many concerts, recitals and musicals as conductor, violinist and
manager. He also sang in male
quartets. Last spring he conducted Pershing's Band, when it
played his military march, "Victory," at the Fifth Regiment Armory. For many years he has
been in charge of the music at the
Johns Hopkins exercises.
It is always a pleasure to be
able to record any note of protest
against the overwhelming commercialism of the time, and Mr.
Turnbull's decision, therefore, is a
matter of sincere congratulation.

In spite of endless negotiations
on the part of the Debating Council, it is understood that the Usual
triangle inter-collegiate debate—
University of North Carolina,
Virginia and Hopkins—which has
been held for many years, will
not take place this year. The
plan fails because of lack of agreement in the three colleges involved
as to methods of judging the contest.
The dissenting voice comes from
the University of Virginia, who
will not agree to having members
of the faculty at the various in-stitutions act as judges. A stand
in favor of this plan was taken
by the other two parties, and Virginia out-voted will withdraw
from the contest this year.
Hopkins will in all probability
meet North Carolina, either in a
dual debate or in a triangle with
another college yet to be determined. The Debating Council has
already opened negotiations with
Washington and Lee University
to this end.
Last year, on the question of
govermnent ownership of railroads, the University of Virginia was the winner of the triangle, defeating the Hopkins negative team at Charlottesville and
the affirmative team of North
Carolina at Chapel Hill. The
Hopkins affirmative team beat the
negative team of North Carolina
at Homewood.
This year Hopkins is anxious
to debate on the city manager
plan.
